StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Inherited defect in ST6GalNAc1 reveals roles of sialylation in intestinal homeostasis

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: INSTRUCTIONS: This work was supported by the Division of Intramural Research, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, NIH and the Sidra Medicine Internal Research Fund (SDR400013, SDR200070). SK was supported by Japan Research Foundation for Clinical Pharmacology. J.M.F. was supported by the Postdoctoral Research Associate Training Program of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences. A.D.W. was supported by the Emory University M.D./Ph.D. Program, National Institutes of Health M.D./Ph.D. Partnerships Program, National Institutes of Health Oxford-Cambridge Scholars Program, and the International Biomedical Research Alliance. The authors would like to thank Ke Huang, Sandhya Xirasagar, Darrell Hurt, and other members of the Bioinformatics and Computational Biosciences Branch (BCBB), NIAID and Yu Zhang for variant assessment and bioinformatics support. We also thank the Sidra Medicine Genomics and Bioinformatics cores’ teams, notably Dr. Stephan Lorenz, Lisa Mathew, Li Liu, Kun Wang, Fazulur Vempalli, and Ghada Mubarak for technical support. We are grateful to Matthew Freeman in University of Oxford for providing us pLEX-iRHOM2-3xHA and for scientific discussions. We thank Helen Su, Joshua Milner, Juan Ravell and Yu Zhang for invaluable editorial and scientific feedback. The authors declare that they have no competing financial interests. The authors are grateful to Merck Sharp & Dohme Corp., a subsidiary of Merck & Co., Inc., Kenilworth, NJ, USA for generous support. Emilio Flano is an employee of Merck Sharp & Dohme Corp., a subsidiary of Merck & Co., Inc., Kenilworth, NJ, USA. The other authors declare that they have no competing financial interests. Approved Users are expected to acknowledge the Submitting Investigator(s) who submitted data from the original study to an NIH-designated data repository, the primary funding organization that supported the Submitting Investigator(s), and the NIH-designated data repository (e.g., dbGaP). The acknowledgment statement should include the dbGaP accession number to the specific version of the dataset(s) analyzed.

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Controlled-access (GSR are sensitive according to the Institutional Certification)

ConsentGroup.title: General Research Use (IRB)
ConsentGroup.name: GRU-IRB
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of the data is limited only by the terms of the model Data Use Certification. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval.
